Eine digitale Quellensammlung und ein Wörterbuch ihrer juridisch-politischen Sprache" der Akademie der Wissenschaften und der Literatur, Mainz, kodiert. Dieses Projekt zielt neben der Herstellung eines Wörterbuchs auf die freie und leicht zugängliche Präsentation wichtiger Texte aus dem Diskussionszusammenhang der sog. "Schule von Salamanca" ab, die hierfür (i.d.R.) aus den Erst-Drucken retrodigitalisiert werden. This document was encoded within the scope of the project "The School of Salamanca. A Digital Collection of Sources and a Dictionary of its Juridical-Political Language" of the Akademie der Wissenschaften und der Literatur, Mainz. Besides creating a dictionary, the project aims at a freely available and easily accessible collection of important texts from the discoursive context of the so called "School of Salamanca", which are being digitized for this purpose (usually in the form of their initial edition). A critical revision, or a recourse to manuscript templates, for instance, has been refrained from.

Este documento se codificó en el marco del proyecto "La Escuela de Salamanca. Una colección digital de fuentes y un diccionario de su lenguaje jurídico-político" de la Akademie der Wissenschaften und der Literatur, Mainz. Además de la producción de un diccionario, el proyecto tiene como objetivo la presentación gratuita y accesible de textos importantes del contexto de discusión de la llamada "Escuela de Salamanca", que se digitalizan (básicamente en la forma de su primera publicación). Se ha prescindido tanto de una revisión crítica, como de un recurso que muestre los originales de los manuscritos o otras ediciones.

item.ref: 2 Infidelitas in the School of Salamanca
2.3 The theological and ethical dimension: infidelitas as sin affecting the moral capacity of the agent
2.4.5 Communication and convivencia: Social relations between Christians and infidels
2.4.6 Commercial relations between Christians and infidels

div.head: 1 Definition and contexts of discussion
div.p: The authors of the School of Salamanca define infidelitas as the deliberate rejection of the (totality of the) Christian faith. The exact understanding of terms like “deliberate”, “rejection” or “totality”, however, was a matter of debate.

Discussions of infidelitas and its related issues usually take their starting point from Thomas Aquinas’ STh IIa-IIae, q. 10, q. 10. Other authors frequently referred to are Augustine, Sylvester and Cajetan.

The Salamancan authors’ discussions of infidelity are shaped by questions arising from the practical experiences of missionaries in the Americas, leading to original departures from the medieval tradition.

div.head: 1.1 Related concepts
div.p: apostasia, bellum, culpa, dominium iurisdictionis, dominium proprietatis, fides, haeresia, ignorantia, iudicium, iuramentum, iurisdictio, ius communicandi, ius peregrinandi, ius praedicandi, peccatum, servitus, superstitio

div.head: 1.2 Particular groups of infidels
div.p: infidelis (etnicus, iudaeus, paganus, saracenus)

div.n: 2 Infidelitas in the School of Salamanca
div.head: 2 Infidelitas in the School of Salamanca
2.1 Defining infidelitas
div.p: The Salamancan authors follow Thomas Aquinas’ bipartite definition (Aquinas, ST IIa-IIae, q. 10): in the negative sense, infidelity is the simple absence of faith. In the second definition, as contempt of the Christian faith or as refusal to be instructed in it, it represents a sin against the faith (Aquinas, ST II-IIae, q. 10 art. 1, p. 78; see Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 1 no. 1, p. 160; Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 3, p. 64).

In the late 16th century, Báñez refines this definition. Infidelity in the negative sense can be understood in two ways: as a lack of the intellectual capacity to receive and understand the faith, or as the absence of faith in an intellectually capable human being. Positive infidelity, always a sin, requires the explicit rejection of the faith or its non-acceptance despite sufficient instruction (Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 1, col. 559).

Manuals for confessors (e.g. Vitoria 1562/2018) define infidelity as an offence against the first of the Ten Commandments. It means rejecting the faith deliberately and consciously, which distinguishes it from minor infringements (Vitoria 1562, Orden de confessarse, Primer mandamiento, Jnfidelidad, p. 21). For Suárez, infidelity cuts a person off from Church and salvation: the infidel denies God’s infallible truth and the divine means of redemption, as if God is capable of lying or cheating (Suárez 1621, disp. 16 sect. 1 no. 1, pp. 262 sq.).

div.head: 2.2.1 Conceptual distinctions: modes of infidelitas
div.p: Concerning the modes of infidelity, most Salamancan authors take Cajetan’s comments on Aquinas, STh IIa-IIae, q. 10, art. 2 as a starting point. Vitoria approves Cajetan’s differentiation of four modes of infidelity based on intellectus but underlines that three of these can also be ascribed to a person’s will (voluntas), given that men are obliged to believe “because of God’s authority and because the Church says so” (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 2 no. 3, p. 164). For Vitoria, the only solely intellectual mode of infidelity is the negative one: the infidel who knows nothing of the faith cannot be said to have voluntas regarding it; he can neither dissent nor doubt.

Suárez offers his own tripartite distinction: refusal to believe the principles of the faith; suspension of judgement; doubts about the Christian precepts. In his view, only the categorical refusal of the Christian faith is clearly sinful (Suárez 1621, disp. 16, sect. 1, no. 8 sq., p. 264).

Suárez also offers further criteria for differentiation: infidelity can also be defined in terms of content (materialiter) or form (formaliter). Materialiter, Christian sinners who ‘ignore’ a certain part of the faith are to be distinguished from infidels ‘ignoring’ the entire contents of the faith, even the First Truth (infidelitas secundum materiam: Suárez 1621, disp. 16 sect. 1 no. 3, p. 263). Infidelitas secundum formam comprises two subtypes: negative and privative. Negative infidelity affects those who are completely ignorant of the faith due to geographical isolation. Suárez argues that this kind of sinless infidelity may be difficult to conceive but is nevertheless possible. As the will of the infidel is not involved, negative infidelity does not constitute a sinful rejection of the faith. Privative infidelity, by contrast, is always sinful because in this case, the infidel turns away from Christianity despite sufficient instruction (Suárez 1621, disp. 16 sect. 1 no. 4, p. 263).

div.head: 2.2.2 Experience-based distinctions: groups of infidels
div.p: Other classifications of infidelity are based on the three ways of rejecting Christianity describes by Aquinas, STh IIa-IIae q. 10 art. 5, who distinguishes between pagans (never having received the faith at all), Jews (recognising the faith only in figura, i.e. in the prophecies of the Old Testament), and heretics (rejecting the manifest truth of the New Testament as taught by the Catholic Church) (Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 5, p. 278; Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 5, col. 595).

Further subdivisions are rejected as unfounded and of little use for answering practical questions, and in order to avoid an endless differentiation (Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 5, p. 279; Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 5, cols. 596-597; Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 5 no. 2, p. 184). Despite broadly agreeing on classification, Salamancan authors frequently disagree on concrete issues. A catechumen who embraces the Christian faith in general terms but insists on disagreeing on a certain point, for example, is considered a heretic by Báñez and Suárez (Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 5, col. 596; Suárez 1621, disp. 16 sect. 4 no. 9, p. 270), whereas Vitoria sees him as the pagan, Jew or Muslim that he was before his conversion (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 5 no. 4, p. 185).

Salamancan scholars make innovative contributions to Catholic thought on infidelity mainly as a result of their reflections on the experiences of extra-European missions. In addition, they adopt the innovative jurisdictional classification originally formulated in the early 16th century by Matías de Paz and Cajetan (Paz 2017, no. 8, pp. 86 sqq.; Aquinas/Cajetan 1897, q. 66 art. 8, comm., pp. 94 sq.; Soto 1553, pars 1 lib. 5 q. 3 art. 5, pp. 430sq.). Adding to the typologies based on European experiences, the authors distinguish between infidel subjects of Christian rulers (e.g. Jews, Muslims or heretics under the dominion of Christian princes), infidels living in formerly Christian lands (e.g. Turks or Saracens), and infidels living in lands which neither belonged to the Roman Empire nor had ever been under the jurisdiction of any Christian prince (e.g. Amerindians). Las Casas underlines how this third category ‘brought light into the former blindness’ (Las Casas 1876, cap. 38, p. 63).

Aiming to develop evangelisation strategies fitting the cultural characteristics of different infidel peoples, Acosta proposes grouping Asian, African, American and Oceanian (Solomon Islands) infidels into three types, according to what he perceives as their respective degree of reason (recta ratio: Acosta 1588, prooem., pp. 117-122). By the 17th century, these typologies of infidelity commonly appear in the juridical and pragmatic literature (Solórzano 1629, lib. 2 cap. 10, 11, pp. 348-372; Peña Montenegro 1668, lib. 2 tract. 8 sess. 5, pp. 220 sqq.).

Reacting to debates about new types of (European) infidelity in the 17th century, Suárez discusses whether atheism and philosophical deism should be considered new kinds of infidelity or whether their adherents can be subsumed under the main Thomist categories. He concludes that the latter should be kept for practical reasons (Suárez 1621, disp. 16 sect. 4 no. 10-15, pp. 270 sqq.).

div.head: 2.3 The theological and ethical dimension: infidelitas as sin affecting the moral capacity of the agent
div.p: There is no consensus in the theological tradition regarding the question to what extent infidelity affects the moral capacity of an agent. Augustine of Hippo considered infidels incapable of true virtue, good actions and legitimate dominium, all of them gifts of divine grace (see Solórzano 1629, lib. 2 cap. 10 no. 26, p. 354); any seemingly virtuous action of Greek or Roman pagans is based only on vainglory or greed (Vázquez 1606b, q. 109 cap. 4 no. 18, p. 523). Vitoria and Vázquez explicitly reject Augustine’s position and similar statements by Gregory of Rimini (Vitoria 1557b, 319; Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 4, pp. 17 sqq.; Vázquez 1606b, q. 109 cap. 1, pp. 519 sq.). For them, an action corresponding to the natural recta ratio should be understood as implicitly corresponding to God’s intentions (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 5 no. 13, pp. 181 sq.) and referring virtualiter to him (Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 4, p. 268). Such good actions are carried out just as God intends; hence, they are virtuous, as are their agents, even if they are infidels lacking knowledge of God. Many Salamancan authors (see the list given by Solórzano 1629, q. 10 cap. 11 no. 50, p. 370) underline that infidelity does not preclude a person from leading a life pleasing to God (Vitoria 1557b, pars 1 no. 40, pp. 346 sq., pars 3 no. 14, p. 393; Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 4, col. 589). Even if very difficult (Vázquez 1606b, q.109 cap. 2, pp. 520 sqq.), it is not impossible for an individual affected by the “mental blindness” of infidelity to live free of sin (Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 3, p. 261).

Over time, this positive view becomes common opinion (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 4 no. 4, p. 171; Suárez 1621, disp. 17 sect. 3 no. 3 sqq., p. 280 sq.), marginalising Augustine’s “exaggerated” criticism (Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 4, col. 587; Suárez 1621, disp. 16 sect. 2 no. 2, p. 265). Augustinian authors have to reinterpret the words of their order’s founder to dissociate his position from that of Luther and other thinkers who hold that virtuous actions could only result from divine grace (Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 4, pp. 271 sq.). In this, the Tridentine canons against Luther, as well as the condemnation of John Wycliff and Jan Hus (both radical interpreters of Augustine’s view on infidels’ moral capacity) formulated by the Council of Constance (1415) are important points of reference in Salamancan literature (Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 4, col. 588; Báñez 1594, q. 62, praeamb. de Dominio, 1a q., p. 123; Solórzano 1629, lib. 2 cap. 10 no. 56, p. 359).

Despite being conscious of the contrary opinion in the theological tradition, Vitoria’s confidence in infidels' capacity for a virtuous life leads him to speculate about the possibility that individuals affected by purely negative infidelity are capable of authentic contrition and thus of receiving grace (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 1 no. 10, pp. 162 sq.; Vitoria 1557a, pars 1 no. 33, p. 337). This view divides his colleagues and is greatly criticised. In 1547, Melchor Cano uses his first public lecture to rebut precisely this opinion of the recently deceased Vitoria (Cano 1550, p. 2, ff. 13r-13v). The pragmatic literature considers it detrimental to evangelising zeal or even heretical (Azpilcueta 1556, cap. 11 no. 18, p. 70; Acosta 1588, lib. 5 cap. 4, pp. 494 sqq.). This may explain why Soto, after initially following Vitoria (Soto 1547, cap. 19, fol. 140v), backs down in response to heavy criticism (Peña Montenegro 1668, lib. 2 tract. 8 sess. 4 no. 3, p. 219; Soto 1557, dist. 1 q. 2 art. 3, pp. 47 sq.).

Underlying the whole debate is the view that in certain cases, infidelity is produced by ignorantia invincibilis, i.e. a complete, guiltless lack of knowledge about the Christian faith due to geographical isolation, lack of preachers, etc. (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 1 no. 1, p. 163; Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 1, p. 254). The Salamancans here follow Aquinas’ and Augustine’s position against more modern authors, such as Hadrian VI, Gabriel Biel, Jean Gerson, Hugh of Saint-Victor, William of Paris and William of Auxerre, for whom infidelity is always inexcusable and sinful (Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 1, cols. 557-558; Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 1, pp. 253 sq.). The latter hold that individuals who have full use of reason but lack faith must have rejected an inner instinct that should lead them towards God; also, if they strictly observed natural law, God himself would enlighten them through an internal revelation or by external means, such as by sending preachers or angels (see Báñez 1584, q. 10 art. 1, col. 557). The Salamancan authors do admit that infidels without any knowledge of the faith are damned – not, however, as a result of their infidelity, but due to other sins committed against natural law. At the turn of the 17th century, this position becomes the common opinion among the Salamancan scholars (see Suárez 1621, disp. 17 sect. 1 no. 5, p. 275).

The theoretical argument about ignorantia invincibilis opens up a practical discussion regarding the teaching of the Gospel in the missionary field. Discussing the missionary practices in the Americas, most authors consider superficial teaching insufficient; Vitoria states that in order to label someone a “contumacious infidel” (infidelis per contrarietatem), he must have had the opportunity of hearing at least the main articles of Christianity presented in a convincing way (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 1 no. 10, p. 162). Suárez, by contrast, holds that even an insufficient proposition of the faith obliges the infidel to seek further information, as the rational character of the Christian precepts cannot be easily brushed away (Suárez 1621, disp. 17 sect. 1 no. 9, p. 276). Other 16th-century authors, however, follow Vitoria’s reasoning, postulating that infidels can only be labelled contumacious if the preacher had been capable of proving that Christian beliefs were more credible than any other cult or religion (Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 1, p. 255).

Contrary to the medieval tradition (see Aquinas IIa-IIae, q. 10, a. 6), Salamancan scholars are not particularly interested in evaluating the wickedness of infidelity compared to other sins and take a casuistic approach, if they discuss the topic at all (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 6 no. 2, p. 187; Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 3 no. 7, p. 169; Suárez 1621, disp. 16 sect. 2, pp. 264 sqq.).

div.head: 2.4 Juridical and political debates
div.p: The theoretical debates on infidelity have important juridical and practical repercussions. To Suárez, the most important aim of doctrinal scholarship is to provide secular and ecclesiastical authorities with criteria to pass laws and judgements which adequately correspond to different kind of infidels, regulating the communication between Christians and infidels, whether they are subjects of the same ruler or not (Suárez 1621, disp. 16 sect. 4, pp. 268 sqq.).

div.head: 2.4.1 Infidelitas and dominium
div.p: One of the most controversial issues is whether infidels are able or allowed to hold property or jurisdiction (dominium). Following Vitoria (Vitoria 1557a, pars 1 no. 7, p. 300), Salamancan authors agree that infidelity does not preclude dominium, since divine positive law and its distinction between believers and infidels does not invalidate natural law (Soto 1553, p. 1 lib. 4 q. 4 art. 1, pp. 302 sq.; Soto 1995, no. 32, pp. 170-173; Freitas 1625, cap. 3 no. 4, fols. 14v-15r; Covarrubias 1573, pars 2 § 10 no. 2, pp. 508 sq.). Jurists like Juan de Solórzano and Gregorio López echo the theologians’ criticism of the position of the 13th-century Italian canonist Henry of Segusio and his followers (Solórzano 1629, lib. 2 cap. 10 no. 57, p. 359) and share their opinion (López 1555, Part. II, Tit. 23, L. 2, Glos. g, fol. 82v) that neither infidelity nor any other kind of mortal sin can cancel dominium or transfer it into the hands of the Church. As stated by the Council of Constance, dominium is instituted by human reason and natural law, not founded on faith and grace.

The topic of dominium is the starting point of discussions on war, slavery and forced conversions. Rejecting Aquinas' general justification of plundering the goods of foreign infidels (Aquinas, STh IIa-IIae, q. 66, art. 8), Vitoria denies that infidelity in itself gives a legitimate reason for war and plunder (Vitoria 1557a, pars 1 no. 31, p. 328; see already Cajetan’s commentary at Aquinas/Cajetan 1897, q. 66 art. 8 comm., pp. 94 sq.). Both jurists and theologians follow him: since a war declared exclusively on account of the opponent's infidelity is unjust, it is also unjust to enslave infidels or to deprive them of their goods without another, legitimate reason (e.g. attacks, blasphemies, or other injustices: Covarrubias 1573, pars 2 § 10 no. 1, p. 508; Acosta 1588, lib. 2 cap. 2, p. 214). However, Saracens and Turks are unanimously considered sworn enemies of Christianity: they, therefore, can be legitimately fought and enslaved and their goods plundered even in the absence of a current and substantive threat (Soto 1553, p. 1 lib. 5 q. 3 art. 5, pp. 430 sq.; Freitas 1625, cap. 9 no. 10, fols. 95v-96r).

div.head: 2.4.2 Infidel subjects of Christian rulers
div.p: In the case of infidels subject to the authority of Christian princes, their infidelity and relations with Christian subjects tend to be viewed as a matter of political regulation; thus, instead of the casuistic discussion regarding war (see 2.4.1), authors apply the criminal legal framework regarding rebellion and anti-Christian proselytism to justify the punitive confiscations and enslavement campaigns suffered by the moriscos after their defeat in the Alpujarras in 1501 (Báñez 1594, q. 57 art. 3, p. 22; Molina 1593, tract. 2 disp. 33, col. 239). Heretics, too, lose their rights to goods and authority over subjects because of their infidelity (Castro 1547, cap. 6, fols. 95r sqq.).

For the Americas, where the infidel subjects of the Crown outnumber the Christians, fiscal issues need to be re-evaluated. Some authors, driven by missionary zeal, suggest imposing high tax rates on contumacious infidels (Acosta 1588, lib. 3 cap. 13, p. 329). But mostly this idea is rejected: while infidel subjects can be compelled to pay higher taxes, they are not to be oppressed by an excessive and tyrannical burden. Such a policy is denounced not only as contradicting Christian magnanimity but also as a covert form of illegitimate forced conversion (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 8 no. 11, p. 195). Vera Cruz instead suggests that tax under a Christian ruler should always be less than under preceding non-Christian authorities (Vera Cruz 2007, no. 822, p. 172). In the case of Christians living or trading under the jurisdiction of infidel rulers, the latter’s infidelity is not considered a legitimate reason not to pay taxes (Ledesma 1617b, tract. 7, p. 193).

div.head: 2.4.3 Infidel rulers
div.p: While the Salamancan authors agree that infidelity as such does not detract from the infidels’ ownership of goods (dominium rerum suis), they reach no consensus regarding the jurisdictional rights (dominium iurisdictionis) of infidel lords. Generally, Christians are supposed not to allow an infidel to acquire rule over Christians, lest the scandalum endanger their faith. In the Salamancan authors’ opinion, this does not, however, invalidate an infidel lord’s pre-existing authority. This position of the School – one of its most distinctive – explicitly disagrees with summistae such as Angelo da Chiavasso, who consider an infidel’s jurisdiction null and void (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 10 no. 1,2, p. 200 sq.), instead following Aquinas. Vitoria and Covarrubias list different reasons for waging a just war against infidel rulers, e.g. if they forbid or obstruct the preaching of the Christian faith or conversions (Vitoria 1557a, pars 2 no. 7, p. 364; Covarrubias 1573, pars 2 § 10 no. 3, pp. 509 sq.). All other titles of just war against infidel authorities (ius peregrinandi, settlement rights, exploitation of natural resources, intervention to help oppressed innocents, etc.) are not based on theological arguments but on the ius gentium; in principle, they thus apply to infidel as well as Christian rulers. Later Salamancans develop Vitoria’s ideas on the ius praedicandi in ever-growing detail. Gregorio de Valencia allows the use of force against any attempt to prevent the preaching of the gospel, but not for compelling infidels living under an infidel prince to listen (Valencia 1603, disp. 1 q. 10 punct. 6, cols. 428-429). Suárez holds that infidels interested in Christianity are justified in their political resistance against magistrates or rulers trying to prevent them listening to Christian preaching. He also sees external intervention by a Christian prince in their support as legitimate (Suárez 1621, q. 18 sect. 2 no. 8, p. 287).

Some authors consider only actual obstruction of preaching or the persecution of Christian subjects as justification for what they call an “indirect” (Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 5 no. 8 sq., p. 294) annulment of an infidel’s rule (De la Peña 1982, p. 154). But a growing majority tend to consider already the potential threat an infidel ruler presents to a people being converted to Christianity as sufficient for intervention (Avendaño 1668, tit. 1 cap. 1 § 3 no. 13, p. 4). According to Acosta, Christian subjects of infidel rulers are always at risk, as shown by the Portuguese failures to evangelise Africa. From his mission-centred perspective, the adoption of preventive measures seems justified (Acosta 1588, lib. 3 cap. 2, pp. 282 sqq.). Later in the 17th century, after experiences with different European and extra-European rulers who received baptism without a sincere will to convert, Avendaño considers even the conversion of a former infidel or heretical prince as an insufficient warrant against a real danger to the Catholic faith (Avendaño 1668, tit. 1 cap. 1 § 3 no. 13, p. 4).

Sins against natural law, thought to be prompted by infidelity, are not regarded as sufficient reason for Christian intervention (ius naturalis, peccatum). According to Vitoria, Soto and other theologians and jurists (for a detailed list, see Freitas 1625, cap. 9 no. 2, fol. 94r), neither the pope nor Christian rulers have the jurisdiction to punish foreign infidels’ sins (Vitoria 1557a, pars 1 no. 40, p. 344; Soto 1553, p. 1 lib. 5 q. 3 art. 5, p. 431; Covarrubias 1573, pars 2 § 10 no. 5, pp. 510 sq.). Later authors consider the opposite view unjust: similar violations, they argue, are committed daily in the Christian world, too, without justifying a war (Valencia 1603, disp. 1 q. 10 punct. 7, cols. 432-436; Vázquez de Menchaca 1572, cap. 24 no. 5, fol. 66r).

div.head: 2.4.4 Baptism of infidels
div.p: Following Aquinas (Aquinas/Cajetan 1895, q. 10 art. 8, pp. 88 sqq.), Salamancan scholars almost unanimously reject forced conversions as contradicting the voluntariness required in the act of faith. Only heretics who have already once received the Catholic faith can be forced to keep their obedience. For Vitoria and others, forced conversions are contrary to natural law and illegitimate, even if applied to infidel subjects of Christian princes (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 8 no. 3, p. 191). Following Aquinas, the School of Salamanca opposes the followers of Duns Scotus, who argue that infidel subjects of Christian princes to whom the faith has been sufficiently preached can be coerced to convert (Scotus, In quartum sententiarum, Dist. 4 q. 9; cf. the nuanced position of Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 8 no. 4, 5, pp. 192 sq.). Also, Vitoria and later Salamancans openly voice their doubts about the legitimacy and efficacy of the policy of forced conversions to which the Spanish Crown subjected its Jewish and Saracen Peninsular subjects during the 16th century (Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 3 no. 13, p. 290; Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 8 no. 5, p. 193). For Suárez, the distinction between infidels who lived under Christian rule and those who do not mattered. While the latter cannot be forced to hear Christian preaching, a prince can oblige his vassals to receive religious indoctrination under threat of monetary penalty or exile: a kind of legitimate coertio indirecta (Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 2 no. 4 sq., p. 286 and disp. 8 sect. 3 no. 8 sqq., p. 289 sq.; libertas). This is to be restricted to exceptional cases, as forced conversions result in dissimulation, sacrileges, blasphemies, and the scandalisation of infidels (Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 3 no. 10, pp. 289 sq.; Peña Montenegro 1668, lib. 2 tract. 8 sess. 5 no. 6-8, p. 221; simulatio, sacrilegium, blasphemia, scandalum). In any case, the temples and public worship of infidels who adhere to a monotheistic religion are to be respected (Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 4 no. 9, p. 292).

The complex conceptual framework developed by Vitoria and others shapes missionary activities, including the consolidation of rigorous catechisation strategies (Peña Montenegro 1668, lib. 2 tract. 8 sess. 8 no. 1, p. 226). Infidelity is more than not being baptised. Hence, the reception of baptism is not enough to turn an infidel adult into a “true Christian” (Vitoria 1967, pp. 157 sqq.). As the degree of grace conferred by a sacrament depends on the disposition to receive it, adequate catechisation is indispensable (Vitoria/Chaves 1561, De Sacr. Bapt, q. 15, fol. 16r).

For adults, the transition to Christianity is understood as a process of progressively overcoming ignorance and moral errors but accompanied by the permanent risk of a return to non-Christian beliefs (apostasia). Following Aquinas against Duns Scotus, Vitoria cites the risk of apostasy as the main reason not to baptise infidel children without parental consent, even if the parents are slaves of a Christian master. He also rejects the abduction of infidel children with the aim of educating them as Christians as an aberration contrary to divine and natural law, as both grant parents the potestas over their offspring (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 12, pp. 203 sqq., q. 10 art. 12 no. 14, 15, pp. 210 sq.; pater). In the field, missionaries sometimes see things differently. Vera Cruz rejects Vitoria’s positions, embracing instead Scotus’ perspective regarding the baptism of infidel children (Vera Cruz 2007, no. 761, p. 158).

div.head: 2.4.5 Communication and convivencia: Social relations between Christians and infidels
div.p: The Salamancan scholars inherit an intense discussion on the ‘communication’ between Christians and infidels from the late medieval tradition (see Aquinas STh IIa-IIae q. 10, a. 9). Actual or potential dangers to the faith mark the limits of interreligious coexistence. Interactions between Christians and infidels are evaluated in a casuistic and prudential way (Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 6, pp. 295 sqq.), taking into account specific circumstances, including the intellectual capacity of those involved: the simpler the Christian and the more educated the infidel, the greater the danger to the Christian faith (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 9 no. 5, p. 199). In line with tradition (Prierias 1518, De Infidelitate, fol. 249v), authors tend to prohibit any situation in which a non-Christian exercised economic, social or other superiority over Christians: accordingly, Jews and other infidels are not allowed to have Christian servants or to hold public offices in a Christian polity (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 9 no. 5, p. 199; Azor 1613, lib. 8 cap. 22, p. 553; Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 5 no. 12 sqq., pp. 295 sq.).

Various restrictions apply to social life. Although an infidel can perform a valid baptism in case of need (Azpilcueta 1556, cap. 22 no. 6, p. 389), he cannot become a godparent. Suárez extends the traditional prohibition for Jews to inherit from Christians to Muslims (seen as enemies of Christians), but not to gentiles or pagans (Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 6 no. 10 sq., p. 297).

Many traditional regulations concerning food and common meals are meant to reduce the interaction of Christians with other religious communities to the minimum needed for the common good of a multireligious republic (Azor 1613, lib. 8 cap. 22, p. 553; Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 6 no. 7, p. 297). Sacred spaces are also the object of detailed regulations. On the one hand, Christians are protected against possible contamination stemming from synagogues, mosques, and other temples: visiting them (let alone participating in rites and celebrations) is strictly forbidden (Azor 1613, lib. 8 cap 22, pp. 553 sq.; Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 6 no. 2, p. 296). On the other, pragmatic literature offers rules to preserve the purity of Christian temples and spaces against any kind of infidel contamination, e.g. improper burials (Azpilcueta 1556, cap. 27 no. 253, p. 777).

Convivencia remains a controversial issue. Before the Rebellion of the Alpujarras (1568-71), social interactions in everyday life tend to be considered licit and even welcome: Vitoria holds that daily contact with Christians, e.g. sharing meals or accommodation or taking a walk together, will lead to the conversion of infidels such as Saracens (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 9 no. 5, p. 199). By the 17th century, however, authors like Azor usually recommend Christians avoid such familiarity.

The most original contributions result from the attempt to provide models for interaction specifically for Christians and infidels living together in the Americas. As the “obstinate perfidy” (Azor 1613, lib. 8 cap. 22, p. 553) attributed to Jews and Muslims can hardly be attributed to the Amerindians, classical frameworks have to be revised. The inner logic of traditional regulations is reversed: in Europe, the faith of old Christians had to be protected in contacts with Jews and Muslims; in the Americas, the faith of neophytes and the good opinion of the sympathetic infidels need protection against scandalum caused by the pernicious behaviour of Christian soldiers, encomenderos (encomienda) or immoral clergymen (Acosta 1589, lib. 3 cap. 5, pp. 293 sqq.). These normative aims inspire different projects of concentration and isolation of indigenous infidels in pueblos de indios, reducciones or hospitals to which only missionaries had access. Theological debates with infidels are considered not only licit but mandatory if they are likely to confirm the superiority of the Christian faith (Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 7, p. 283). Traditionally, they are regarded as indispensable in lands being converted, while their utility seems dubious where the Christian doctrine has already been consolidated (Aquinas/Cajetan 1895, q. 10 art. 7, pp. 87 sq.). Different Salamancan approaches reflect a growing awareness of the varying views on the rationality and generalisability of Christian doctrine, e.g. acknowledging that some dogmas can only be proved imperfectly or that Catholics, heretics, and Jews at least partially share a belief in the authority of the Bible or at least parts of it (Vitoria 1932, q. 9 art. 7 no. 3, pp. 189 sq.; Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 7, p. 284).

div.n: 2.4.6 Commercial relations between Christians and infidels
div.head: 2.4.6 Commercial relations between Christians and infidels
div.p: Interreligious commercial relations are one of the most regulated fields. Legal and theological norms generally allow these if they serve the interest of Christian realms. The principle of good faith, seen as indispensable for the reliability of contracts and the survival of society, is also mandatory in trade with infidels (Ledesma 1617b, tract. 7, p. 193). Canon law prohibits the sale of potentially harmful goods to hostile infidels, e.g. weapons. The same applies to the sale of products to be used in non-Christian religious rites (Vitoria 1557a, pars 1 no. 14, p. 303). Azpilcueta refers to recent legal provisions, like Julius III’s bull In Coena Domini (1550), which extends the penalty of excommunication to merchants selling arms to all hostile pagans, not just Turks and Saracens (Azpilcueta 1556, cap. 27 no. 61, p. 660). While upholding the medieval framework, Salamancan authors tend towards greater flexibility. They explicitly do not follow the Summa Rosella (1482) and the Summa sylvestrina (Prierias 1518, De Infidelitate, fol. 249v) by refusing to blame merchants for selling goods to infidels that can be employed for multiple purposes, even if they know that the infidels will use them for their religious rites (Vitoria 1932, q. 10 art. 12 no. 2, p. 202 sq.; Aragón 1584, q. 10 art. 5., p. 273; Ledesma 1617b, tract. 1, p. 23; Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 6 no. 2, p. 296). Jurists complement canon law and theological authorities with secular law that regulated commerce with infidels since the Middle Ages, e.g. referring to the Siete Partidas to justify that Christian helmsmen guiding the ships of infidel enemies or merchants selling arms to them are punished by enslavement (Hevia de Bolaños 1629, lib. 1 cap. 12 no. 2, pp. 119 sq.).

div.head: 2.4.7 Infidels and (Christian) marriage
div.p: One of the most discussed topics is interreligious matrimonium. In line with tradition, a marriage between a Christian and a non-baptised partner (even if already a catechumen) is null and void (Suárez 1621, disp. 18 sect. 6 no. 3, p. 296; Azpilcueta 1556, cap. 22 no. 49, p. 413). Marriages between infidels are generally considered legitimate if they do not contravene natural law. These unions, however, do not have the same status as a Christian marriage, the only one considered indissoluble once consummated: when one spouse converts to Christianity, the marriage is not dissolved ipso facto, but divorce becomes possible if the infidel spouse represents a threat to the converted partner’s faith. The baptised partner can subsequently enter a Christian marriage (Azpilcueta 1556, cap. 22 no. 49, pp. sq.). A controversial question is whether the marriage of two infidels has to be repeated according to the Christian rite (in facie ecclesiae) after the baptism of both spouses. As it is impossible to formally repeat the marriages of all baptised Amerindians, pragmatic solutions are suggested. Vera Cruz holds that baptism itself was enough to make the marriage fully sacramental (Vera Cruz 1562, pars 2 art. 36, pp. 452 sq.). He even proposes that marriages between infidels contracted in strict compliance with natural law have a certain sacramental character (Vera Cruz 1562, pars 2 art. 35, p. 451), a claim that leads to an intense debate within the School of Salamanca (Azpilcueta 1556, cap. 22 no. 48, 49, pp. 412 sq.; Ledesma 1617a, cap. 24, pp. 522 sqq.).

div.head: 3 Final remark
div.p: One of the more conspicuous results of the Salamancan debates is that in many political-juridical discussions, the concept of infidelitas no longer plays a major role: for example, it cannot be used to great effect anymore in subsequent discussions about property or just war. For an overview of research literature (18th century – 2018) discussing infidelitas throughout history, see the bibliography in Meyer (2020).
